None
No national population register; identity is verified against issuing agencies Erecords without creating a centralised database.

No
No nationwide resident registry network comparable to population-register linkage.

Restricted
Identity documents (passport, driver licence) are used to create Digital ID; unique identifiers are purpose-bound rather than universal cross-sector IDs.

Partial
Australian Government Digital ID System enables online verification against official records with user consent (no central database).

No
No national ID card; government Digital ID relies on existing identity documents (passport, driver licence) as evidence.

Nationwide
myID (formerly myGovID) is the Australian Government Digital ID app used to prove identity for online services.

Partial
Digital driver licences are state-based (e.g., NSW Digital Driver Licence in Service NSW app).

Yes
Digital ID (myID) provides authentication and identity proofing for participating government services.

Procurement
Whole-of-government cloud policy provides a unified framework for cloud adoption across the Australian Public Service.

No
No EU GDPR adequacy decision for Australia (not listed among adequacy jurisdictions).

Yes
Key milestones captured in events.csv

None
No national population register; core identity and licensing records are managed by provinces/territories.

No
No single nationwide resident registry network comparable to population-register linkage.

Restricted
Social Insurance Number is confidential; use is legally required mainly for income reporting and government benefits.

Partial
Digital government access uses multiple credentials (GCKey, Sign-In Partner) and program-specific enrolment.

No
No federal national ID card; commonly used credentials include provincial driver’s licences/ID and passports.

Partial
Some provinces offer digital ID login apps (e.g., BC Services Card app) for online access to services.

None
No nationwide mobile driver’s licence (mDL) acceptance; provinces issue physical licences and require carrying a driver’s licence when driving.

Multiple
Authentication uses GCKey plus Sign-In Partner (bank-based) and some provincial sign-in options.

Procurement
Government of Canada cloud adoption is guided by the Cloud Adoption Strategy (cloud smart) and security baselines such as GC Cloud Guardrails; cloud use is managed through policy, assurance and procurement frameworks rather than a single, public, unified 'government cloud' product brand.
change_note: Finalize I09 wording; remove needs-review after evidence update

value:
Adequacy
EU recognises Canada (commercial organisations) as providing adequate protection for personal data transfers.

Yes
Key milestones captured in events.csv

Local
Population registers are kept by registration authorities designated by each Land; registration is handled by municipalities.

Partial
Population registers are maintained locally; data exchange occurs under the Federal Act on Registration rather than a single national resident registry network.

Restricted
No universal cross-sector identifier; sector identifiers exist (e.g., tax) and online identity uses the ID card eID function.

Partial
Digital government services use user accounts (BundID) and standards, but interoperability remains federated across federal/state levels.

Yes
German ID card (Personalausweis) includes a chip enabling online identification (eID).

Partial
Smartphone use typically relies on the ID card eID function via an app/reader; not a standalone mobile-ID credential.

Planned
Germany is preparing for mobile driving licence (mDL) scenarios within EU Digital Identity Wallet pilots; the EU large-scale pilots include an mDL use case. A nationwide ISO/IEC 18013-5 mDL issuance programme is not yet confirmed.
change_note: Update I07 sources to EU pilots

value:
Multiple
Authentication via eID function of the ID card plus BundID user account; also supports EU eID means.

Shared-Platform
Federal cloud initiatives include Bundescloud and the federated German Government Cloud (DVC).

Adequacy
GDPR applies (EU member state).

Yes
Key milestones captured in events.csv

National
Denmark’s civil registration system (CPR) is the national registration system; municipalities handle updates under the CPR framework.

Yes
CPR number is essential for access to public services; eID onboarding can use CPR-linked data for verification.

Common
CPR number is the primary identifier for interaction with Danish public authorities.

Nationwide
Digital self-services rely on CPR and MitID; cross-service access works via shared identity infrastructure.

No
Denmark does not have a mandatory national ID card for residents. Identity is typically proven with passport or driving licence; municipalities can issue an identity card as photo ID in some situations.
change_note: Replace generic CPR source; clarify optional municipal ID card; remove needs-review

value:
Nationwide
MitID is the Danish national eID used for public self-service solutions; can be obtained via app and passport scanning.

Planned
Mobile driving licence (mDL) is being explored within the EU Digital Identity Wallet large-scale pilot use cases; Denmark participates in EU wallet pilots, but a nationwide ISO/IEC 18013-5 mDL issuance programme is not yet confirmed.
change_note: Update I07 sources from generic manual to EU pilot documentation

value:
Yes
MitID is the national eID and key to digital services across Denmark.

Procurement
Government cloud adoption in Denmark is guided via public-sector policy and procurement practices, including official guidance for public authorities on selecting and using cloud services (risk, law, security and contracting considerations).
change_note: Finalize I09 wording; remove needs-review after source update
